Topic 2: Consumer theory

1. Utility maximization problem (UMP)

  • Utility maximization

    (1)maxxU(x)s.t.px≤wx≥0

    Then we can set up the langrage function and use KKT conditions to find possible solutions.

  • Are K-T conditions sufficient?

    Yes, when

    • utility function is twice differentiable and quasi-concave

    • all constraints are linear

    • Ul(x∗)≠0 for some l=1,...,L

  • Marshallian demand function:

    By solving the UMP problem,

    (2)x∗(p,w)=(x1∗(p,w),…,xL∗(p,w))

  • Properties of Marshallian demand function:

    • If the preference is strictly convex, then only one solution bundle remains under budget constraints (if utility function is strictly quasi-concave, then consumption bundle is unique).

      Proof:

      Suppose there are two consumption bundles x1∗ and x2∗ both satisfies the budget constraints,

      Since the preference is strictly convex, then let t∈[0,1], such that tx1∗+(1−t)x2∗≿x1∗,x2∗.

      Which means that x1∗ and x2∗ are not optimal bundle. Contradict!

    • If preference is convex, but not strictly convex, then there might be multiple x∗ that are not unique.

      Proof:

      Suppose we have two optimal consumption bundle x1∗ and x2∗, but we have set of the optimal consumption bundles are not convex.

      which means tx1∗+(1−t)x2∗≺x1∗,

      This means the upper contour set of utility function is not convex. Contradict!

      The set x∗(p,w) has to be convex.

    • x∗(p,w) is homogeneous degree of 0 with respect to (p,w).

      This is because maxxU(x), s.t. px≤w is equivalent to s.t. tpx≤tw.

       

    • When utility is strictly quasi-concave (preference is strictly convex, indifference curve is strictly convex), and monotone, then our Lagrange function with equality constraint could be a sufficient method for solving UMP.

 

  • Indirect utility function: substituting the x∗ into the objective function

(3)v(p,w)=u(x∗(p,w))

  • Properties of indirect utility functions

    • v(p,w) is strictly increasing in w.

      Proof

      (4)V(p1,p2,w)=U(x1w(p1,p2,w),x2w(p1,p2,w))

      对w求偏导数 Diffrentiate w.r.t. w:：

      (5)∂V∂w≡∂U∂x1∂x1w∂w+∂U∂x2∂x2w∂w

      使用一阶条件 FOC：U1=λp1 和 U2=λp2：

      (6)∂V∂w≡λ(p1∂x1w∂w+p2∂x2w∂w).

      现在，当将需求曲线重新插入预算约束中时，我们得到一个恒等式：

      (7)p1x1w+p2x2w≡w

      对其求导，我们得到：

      (8)p1∂x1w∂w+p2∂x2w∂w≡1.

      这给出了：∂V∂w≡λ>0。

    • v(p,w) is homogeneous of degree 0 in (p,w).

      This is because x∗(p,w) is H.D.0, x∗(tp,tw)=x∗(p,w)

    • v(p,w) is quasi-convex in (p,w)

      Proof

      for ∀(p1,w1),(p2,w2),

      Let (for i=1,2)

      (9)vi=v(pi,wi)xi=x∗(pi,wi)

      Define

      (10)pt=tp1+(1−t)p2wt=tw1+(1−t)w2vt=v(pt,wt)xt=x∗(pt,wt)

      , where t∈(0,1)

      If we want show vt=v(pt,wt) is quasi-convex, we have to show

      (11)vt<max{v1,v2}

      Let's prove by contradiction,

      Assume vt>v1,v2, then we have

      (12)p1xt>w1p2xt>w2

      , because p1x1=w1, and to achieve a better utility consumption bundle, the expenditure has to be increased.

      This will result in ptxt>wt since tp1+(1−t)p2>tw1+(1−t)w2. Contradiction!

       

  • Walras' law

    With strictly monotonic preference, we have Walras' law

    (13)pTx∗(p,w)=w

    • Taking derivative w.r.t. w

      (14)∑ℓ=1Lpℓ∂xℓ∂w|x∗=1

      • This means the change in expenditure and the change in wealth must be the same.

      • Not all commodities can be inferior good. Because ∂xℓ∂w<0 for each consumption good will result in a violation of Walras' law.

      • We can derive Engel Aggregation from here:

        (15)∑ℓ=1Lpℓ∂xℓ∂w|x∗=1⇒∑ℓ=1Lηℓsℓ=1

        Note that η represents the income elasticity,

        (16)ηℓ=∂xℓ/xℓ∂w/w=∂xℓ∂wwxℓ

        , and sl represents the expenditure share on good l

        (17)sl=plxlw

      •  

       

    • Taking derivative w.r.t. pj

      (18)xj∗(p,w)+∑ℓ=1Lpℓ∂xℓ∂pj|x∗=0 for all j=1,…,n

      • We can derive the Cournot aggregation

        (19)xj∗(p,w)+∑ℓ=1Lpℓ∂xℓ∂pj|x∗=0⇒∑ℓ=1Lsℓϵℓj=−sj

        Note that ϵij is the price elasticity

        (20)ϵij=∂xi∂pjpjxi

 

  • Roy's identity

    (21)xj∗(p,w)=−∂v(p,w)∂pj∂v(p,w)∂w

    Proof:

    By envelope theorem:

    (22)∂v∂pl=−λxl⋆∂v∂w=λ>0

    Then we have the Roy's identity.

    Intuition:

    • ∂v∂w=λ>0, income more results in more utility

    • ∂v∂pl=−λxl⋆. it is 0 if xl∗=0. If we do not consume on xl, its price have no impact on our utility.

 

2. Expenditure minimization problem (EMP)

  • Hicksian demand and expenditure function

    After solving an EMP, we have Hicksian demand h(p,u) or xh(p,u). And expenditure function e(p,u)=pxh(p,u).

  • Properties of expenditure function

    • strictly increasing in u

      (23)e(p,u)≡minX∈R+npX s.t. U(X)=uL(X,λ)=pX+λ[U−U(X)] FOCs: ∂L(X∗,λ∗)∂Xi=pi−λ∗∂U(X∗)∂xi=0,i=1,2,…,n.

      The solution is : X∗=Xh(p,U)≫0 for p≫0 and U>U(0), i.e. Hicksian demands. Because pi>0 and ∂U(X∗)∂Xi>0, so is λ∗>0, hence by envelope theorem:

      (24)∂e(p,U)∂U=∂L(X∗,λ∗)∂U=λ∗>0

      In this case λ is marginal cost of utility (the inverse of the marginal utility of income). It shows by how much is the minimum expenditure going to increase if we increase utility by a small amount.

    • Non-decreasing in p.

      By Shephard' lemma: ∂e∂pℓ|x∗=hℓ∗(p,u)≥0

    • e(p,u) is homogeneous of degree 1 in prices

      Intuition:

      No relative price change, all price goes up, to reach the same utility, Hicksian demand xh(tp,u)=xh(p,u). Therefore, expenditure e(tp,u)=xh(p,u)×tp, which is H.D.1

    • Concave in p

      Proof:

      Suppose h1 and h2 are solutions to the expenditure minimization problems with p1 and p2 respectively. For ∀t∈[0,1], define pt=tp1+(1−t)p2.

      (25)e(pt,u)≡ptht=tp1ht+(1−t)p2ht≥te(p1,u)+(1−t)e(p2,u)

      Intuition: EMP 解出来是最小的expenditure，任何在这个价格水平下其他达到这个utility的consumption bundle 对应的expenditures 都要更大

     

  • Properties of Hicksian demand function

    • Homogeneous of degree 0 in p

    • No excess utility: u(h(p,u―))=u―, binding constraint and γ∗>0

    • Cross elasticity: ∂hi∂pj=∂2e∂pi∂pj

    • The matrix of own and cross-partial derivatives w.r.t p is symmetric and negative semi-definite - Hicksian substitution matrix e(p,u) is concave in p.

    • Non-positive own-price elasticity: ∂hℓ(p,u)∂pℓ=∂2e(p,u)∂pℓ2≤0

 

3. Duality

When x∗≫0

  • In expenditure minimization: γ∗∇u(x∗)=p

  • In utility maximization: ∇u(x∗)=λ∗p

  • Both give MRSij=pipj

  • In terms of demand functions

(26)h(p,v(p,w))≡x(p,w)x(p,e(p,u))≡h(p,u)

  • In terms of value functions

(27)u≡v(p,e(p,u))w≡e(p,v(p,w))

  • In terms of Lagrange multipliers: γ∗=1λ∗

  • They are dual problems in the sense that they contain the same information

 

3.1 Duality between U(q) and V(p)

U(q) → UMP → x∗(p,w) → V(p,w)=U(x(p,w))

V(p) → Roy's identity: xj∗(p,w)=−∂v(p,w)∂pj∂v(p,w)∂w → U(q)

 

3.2 Indirect utility and expenditure function

(28)u≡v(p,e(p,u))w≡e(p,v(p,w))

3.3 Marshallian and Hicksian demand

By duality, hj(p,u)=xj(p,e(p,u)), thus

(29)∂hj(p,u)∂pi=∂xj(p,w)∂pi+∂xj(p,w)∂w∂e∂pi=∂xj(p,w)∂pi+∂xj(p,w)∂wxi∂xj(p,w)∂pi=∂hj(p,u)∂pi−∂xj(p,w)∂wxi

  • Slutsky equation links the observable x(p,w) to the "useful" h(p,u);

  • The process is called Hicksian decomposition

    • (Hicksian) Substitution effect

    • Income effect

  • More on Hicksian substitution

    • The cross substitution of Hicksian demand is symmatric:

      (30)∂xih(p,U)∂pj=∂xjh(p,U)∂pii,j=1,…,n

      Proof - By the Young's Theorem

      Since we have ∂e(p,U)∂pi=xih(p,U), we can derive

      (31)∂2e(p,U)∂pi2=∂xih(p,U)∂pi≤0.

      , then we have,

      (32)∂xjh∂pi=∂2e(p,U)∂pj∂pi=∂2e(p,U)∂pi∂pj=∂xih∂pj

      That implies the substitutive terms are symmetric.

    • Combining the results, we can derive a matrix

      (33)σ(p,u)≡[∂x1h(p,u)∂p1…∂x1h(p,u)∂pn⋮⋱⋮∂xnh(p,u)∂p1⋯∂xnh(p,u)∂pn]

      called (Hicksian) substitution matrix which has to be negative semidefinite.

  • Slutsky Matrix

    Notice that Slutsky equation can be written as:

    (34)∂xih(p,u)∂pj=∂xiM(p,M)∂pj+xjM∂xiM(p,M)∂M

    So σ(p,U) can be replaced by| the sum of 2 elements on the RHS to obtain Slutsky matrix S(p,M). Obviously:

    (35)σ(p,U)=S(p,M)

    and hence S(p,M) has to be symmetric and negative semi-definite.

  • Slutsky equation in elasticity

    Slutsky equation can be written in dimensionless elasticity form. Multiply by pjxi throughout and the last term by MM=1, we can get

    (36)∂xiM∂pjpjxi=∂xih∂pjpjxi−pjxixjM∂xiM∂MMMϵijM=ϵijh−pjxjMM⏟αjϵiM

    The difference between the (cross) price elasticity of the uncompensated and compensated demand curves depends on income elasticity of the good (i) and the importance of the good whose price has changed (j) measured by its budget share.
